title: Man wrongly accused of being a paedophile because of typo
text:
Nigel Lang was wrongly accused of being a paedophile (Picture: BBC) Typos are easy to make but there are certain errors that have the potential to ruin someone’s life. One July morning in 2011 Nigel Lang found that out for himself when he was arrested by police and accused of being a paedophile all because of an error he had nothing to do with. Mother claims toddler almost became the 'next Maddie McCann' The then 44-year-old was employed as a drug recovery worker at the time, helping young people to combat substance abuse. But his arrest changed all that, leaving his reputation in ‘tatters’. He now has no job and suffers from mental health problems. Tragically, despite being cleared as ‘completely innocent’ after three weeks, it took Nigel years to find out what happened. Nigel Lang appeared on BBC’s Victoria Derbyshire programme to make his innocence public
(Picture: BBC) After being told it would be impossible to tell whether his arrest was the result of a mistake, he then hired a solicitor to get to the bottom of it. What they found was staggering. Clocks go forward this Sunday, don't get caught out Before Nigel’s arrest, South Yorkshire Police had been informed by Hertfordshire Police that an IP address they had identified had been used to share 100 indecent images of children. But officers weren’t aware that the IP address was the result of a typo after an extra digit was added by mistake. In 2014, Nigel received an apology from Hertfordshire Police, which accepted responsibility for the error. The mistake was the result of a typo (Picture: Shutterstock) And in 2016, he received damages of £60,000 plus legal costs from the force. But he has since decided to open up about the ordeal in order to clear his name. More snow on its way as Arctic blast blankets parts of UK He told the BBC ‘s Victoria Derbyshire programme he feels unable to go back into the line of work he was in ‘It was the best job I’d had in my life, and I felt I was really good at it,’ he said. ‘But I became fearful of working with young females in case any of them said I tried any sexual advances. It made me paranoid.’ More: UK New tube maps show how long it takes to walk between stations Boy, 5, gets stuck inside claw toy-grabbing machine Cadbury spends all day explaining why its chocolate is halal Speaking to BuzzFeed News , he added: ‘My personality has changed. I’m more angry, I struggle with a lack of sleep and am hyper-vigilant around people, being paranoid that people are talking about me.’ Hertfordshire Police said in a statement to the BBC it ‘made an early admission of the mistake once it had been identified and would like to apologise again for the wrongful arrest and further impact caused. ‘It was an administrative error which led to this occurring, and lessons have been learnt to help prevent this happening again. ‘This man was completely innocent and compensation has now rightfully been settled.’ MORE: Mother claims toddler almost became the ‘next Maddie McCann’ MORE: Jeremy Kyle devastated following the death of his 85-year-old mother
